title: The happy secret to better work - Shawn Achor

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about the formula for happiness and success?

options.label: A
options.text: The current formula is correct, and people should work harder to be more successful and then they'll be happier.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that success is the only path to happiness.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: Meditating on your failures and setbacks.

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing on the negative aspects of your life.

title: How do we experience time? - Matt Danzico

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how time perception can affect our experience of an event?

options.label: A
options.text: A person who is reading a book may perceive time as passing more quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: A person who is in a car accident may perceive the accident as lasting longer than it actually did.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a lesson that can be learned from time perception?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That we should avoid new experiences to make time seem to pass more quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: That engaging with the world and having new experiences can make our lives seem longer.

options.label: D

options.text: It is too complex.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not work when there are an odd number of people in the room.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not work when there are zero people in the room.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the condition "If 1 person remains unpaired, set n = n + 1" in the revised algorithm?

options.label: A
options.text: To handle the case when there are zero people in the room.

options.label: B
options.text: To handle the case when there are an odd number of people in the room.

options.label: C
options.text: To handle the case when there are an even number of people in the room.

options.label: D
options.text: To handle the case when there are more than 10 people in the room.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to count people in larger groups, such as 5's or 10's?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is too slow.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is too complex.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is hard to point to each person in the group.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not accurate.

title: The Watergate scandal: United States vs. Nixon

multiple-choice.question: What was the event that led to the discovery of the Watergate scandal?

options.label: A
options.text: A security guard noticed a suspicious person around the Watergate complex.

options.label: B
options.text: A security guard noticed that a few doors were taped so that they were left unlocked.

options.label: C
options.text: A security guard received a tip about a potential break-in.

options.label: D
options.text: A security guard saw the burglars entering the complex.

multiple-choice.question: Who were the two reporters from The Washington Post that uncovered information linking the break-in and cover-up to the CIA, FBI, White House, and Justice Department?

options.label: A
options.text: Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein

options.label: B
options.text: John Dean and H.R. Haldeman

options.label: C
options.text: Richard Nixon and Spiro Agnew

options.label: D
options.text: E. Howard Hunt and G. Gordon Liddy

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the "smoking gun" tape in the Watergate scandal?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a conversation between Nixon and Haldeman discussing the cover-up plan.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a conversation between Nixon and John Dean discussing the break-in.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a conversation between Haldeman and Ehrlichman discussing the scandal.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a conversation between Nixon and his personal secretary discussing the tapes.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Watergate scandal on the American public's perception of politicians?

options.label: A
options.text: It increased trust in politicians.

options.label: B
options.text: It decreased trust in politicians.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no effect on trust in politicians.

options.label: D
options.text: It made people more apathetic towards politics.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Richard Nixon decide to resign as President of the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: He was forced to by the Supreme Court.

options.label: B
options.text: He was impeached by the House of Representatives.

options.label: C
options.text: He realized he had lost the support of Congress and the American people.

options.label: D
options.text: He was advised to by his lawyers.

title: The basics of the Higgs boson - Dave Barney and Steve Goldfarb

multiple-choice.question: What is the Higgs field, and what does it do?

options.label: A
options.text: The Higgs field is a type of force field that gives mass to atoms.

options.label: B
options.text: The Higgs field is a hypothetical, invisible kind of force field that pervades the whole universe and gives mass to elementary particles.

options.label: C
options.text: The Higgs field is a type of particle that carries forces.

options.label: D
options.text: The Higgs field is a type of matter that makes up the universe.

multiple-choice.question: What are elementary particles, and what are they made of?

options.label: A
options.text: Elementary particles are the basic building blocks of the universe and are made up of smaller components called quarks.

options.label: B
options.text: Elementary particles are the basic building blocks of the universe and are made up of smaller components called atoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Elementary particles are the basic building blocks of the universe and have no structure.

options.label: D
options.text: Elementary particles are the basic building blocks of the universe and are made up of smaller components called bosons.

multiple-choice.question: How does the Higgs field give mass to particles?

options.label: A
options.text: The Higgs field gives mass to particles by interacting with them and transferring energy.

options.label: B
options.text: The Higgs field gives mass to particles by creating a force field around them.

options.label: C
options.text: The Higgs field gives mass to particles by interacting with them and giving them a property called mass.

options.label: D
options.text: The Higgs field gives mass to particles by producing a particle called the Higgs boson.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Higgs boson, and how is it related to the Higgs field?

options.label: A
options.text: The Higgs boson is a particle that carries forces and is related to the Higgs field.

options.label: B
options.text: The Higgs boson is a particle that is produced by the Higgs field and is an excitation of the field.

options.label: C
options.text: The Higgs boson is a particle that gives mass to other particles and is related to the Higgs field.

options.label: D
options.text: The Higgs boson is a particle that is not related to the Higgs field.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of finding the Higgs boson, and what does it mean for particle physics?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the Higgs boson means that the Higgs field exists, and it confirms the Standard Model of particle physics.

options.label: B
options.text: Finding the Higgs boson means that the Higgs field does not exist, and it contradicts the Standard Model of particle physics.

options.label: C
options.text: Finding the Higgs boson means that particle physics is complete, and there is nothing left to discover.

options.label: D
options.text: Finding the Higgs boson means that particle physics is just beginning, and it opens up new avenues for exploration.

title: Leaders and followers: what tango teaches

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of the leader role in Tango

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of the follower role in Tango

options.label: C
options.text: The history of Tango dance

options.label: D
options.text: The different styles of Tango music

multiple-choice.question: According to Sha and Isaac, what is a common misconception about the follower role in Tango?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That the follower is passive and does not take responsibility for their own movements

options.label: C
options.text: That the follower is only responsible for following the leader's steps

options.label: D
options.text: That the follower is not important in the dance

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: When the follower is too focused on their own steps and ignores the leader's guidance

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It felt like a normal part of the dance

multiple-choice.question: What is the ideal relationship between the leader and follower in Tango, according to Sha and Isaac?

options.label: B
options.text: Complimentary, with both partners working together to create the dance

options.label: C
options.text: Competitive, with the leader and follower trying to outdo each other

options.label: D
options.text: Passive, with the follower relying on the leader to do all the work
